frontmatter.name: Extract Elements of Text
frontmatter.description: Extract specific elements of text from a given text

messages.content:
Extract the important entities mentioned in the text below. First extract all company names, then extract all people names, then extract specific topics which fit the content and finally extract general overarching themes

Desired format:
Company names: <comma_separated_list_of_company_names>
People names: -||-
Specific topics: -||-
General themes: -||-

prompt.content:
---
name: Extract Elements of Text
description: Extract specific elements of text from a given text
source: OpenAI documentation
url: https://help.openai.com/en/articles/6654000-best-practices-for-prompt-engineering-with-the-openai-api
tags:
  - sample
  - unlisted
  - paper
inputs: 
   text:
      type: string
---
system:
Extract the important entities mentioned in the text below. First extract all company names, then extract all people names, then extract specific topics which fit the content and finally extract general overarching themes

Desired format:
Company names: <comma_separated_list_of_company_names>
People names: -||-
Specific topics: -||-
General themes: -||-
user:
Text: {{text}}

intent.content: Extract company names, people names, specific topics, and overarching themes from the provided text and present them in the specified format.

inputSpec.content:
The input is a single natural-language text string containing arbitrary written content.
The input may be any kind of prose such as articles, blog posts, emails, transcripts, lists, or mixed formats.
The text may be in any language, including multilingual or code-switched segments.
The text may contain company names, person names, topics, and themes, but it is valid even if none are present.
The text may include punctuation, numbers, dates, times, currencies, URLs, email addresses, hashtags, mentions, emojis, and other special characters.
The text may include quotations, headers, footers, citations, references, or semi-structured elements rendered as plain text.
The input may range in length from a single word to a long multi-paragraph document.
The text may be empty or whitespace-only.
The text is treated as plain textual content regardless of embedded markup like HTML, markdown, or JSON snippets.
The input does not require any specific structure beyond being a text passage.

rules.content:
The output must consist of exactly four non-empty lines in the fixed order: Company names, People names, Specific topics, General themes.
Each of the four lines must begin with the exact label followed by a colon and a single space, using the exact capitalization and spelling: "Company names: ", "People names: ", "Specific topics: ", and "General themes: ".
After the colon and space on each line, the content must be a comma-separated list of items where items are separated by a comma followed by a single space, with no trailing comma at the end of the line.
Items in the lists must not contain commas themselves, because commas are reserved exclusively as separators between items in the lists.
Each item in any list must be a concise phrase and must not be a complete sentence, and no item may end with a period, question mark, or exclamation mark.
No line may contain any text other than the required label, colon, single space, and the comma-separated list of items; the output must contain no explanations, headings, extra commentary, or echoed input text.
The output must not contain any placeholder symbols or angle-bracket notation, such as "<...>" or "-||-", and must present actual extracted items.
There must be no blank lines before, between, or after the four required lines.
Within each category, items must be unique with no duplicate entries in the same list.
No item may be duplicated across categories; an item appearing in one category must not also appear in any of the other three categories.
Company names are names of business entities mentioned in the input text (such as corporations, companies, firms, startups, or brands), and each company name listed must exactly match a company mention from the input text, allowing differences in letter case only.
People names are names of individual human persons mentioned in the input text, and each listed person name must match a person mention from the input text and may include honorifics or titles (e.g., Mr., Ms., Dr., Prof.) only if they appear with the name in the input text.
Specific topics are concrete, narrowly scoped subjects discussed in the input text, expressed as short noun phrases typically one to four words long, and must not include proper names of companies or people.
General themes are broad, overarching subject areas that summarize the content of the input text at a higher level of abstraction than the specific topics, expressed as short noun phrases typically one to five words long, and must not include proper names of companies or people.
No item listed under Specific topics may be identical to any item listed under General themes.
Each item must be trimmed of leading and trailing whitespace, and there must be exactly one space following each comma separator with no double spaces within any list.
If internal punctuation other than commas appears inside an item (such as hyphens, apostrophes, periods within abbreviations, ampersands, or slashes), it is permitted as part of the item.
Items must not contain URLs, email addresses, hashtags, or social media handles.
Items must not be enclosed in quotation marks or parentheses, and any such surrounding characters present in the input text must be omitted in the lists.
Digits are permitted within items where they are part of the name or phrase (for example, "3D printing").
Each line must end at the final item without a trailing space, and the entire output must be plain text with no bullets, numbering, or markup.

inverseRules.content:
The output may contain any number of lines, including zero or more than four, lines may be empty, and the categories can be omitted, repeated, merged, or appear in any order.
Lines need not begin with those exact labels; any label text (or none) is acceptable with any capitalization, alternative punctuation (e.g., em dash instead of a colon), or extra spacing.
Items do not have to be comma-separated; you may use mixed delimiters (semicolons, pipes, tabs, multiple spaces), inconsistent spacing, and trailing separators or commas are allowed.
Items may freely contain commas and nested comma clauses; commas are not reserved as separators and may appear inside items without quoting.
Items may be full sentences or long descriptions and may end with punctuation such as periods, question marks, or exclamation points.
Lines may include additional text like headings, notes, explanations, or echoed input before or after the lists.
Placeholder symbols and angle-bracket notation (e.g., <...>, -||-, [TBD]) are permitted anywhere, and items need not be real or extracted.
Blank lines are allowed anywhere, including multiple blank lines before, between, and after content.
Duplicate entries within the same category are permitted, including exact duplicates and case-only variations.
The same item may be repeated across different categories verbatim, including being present in all four lists.
Company names may be invented, altered, abbreviated, or paraphrased and need not match any mention in the input text.
People names may include individuals not mentioned in the input, and honorifics or titles may be added or removed arbitrarily.
Specific topics may be broad, vague, or high-level and may include proper names of companies or people.
General themes may be extremely narrow or concrete and may include proper names of companies or people.
It is acceptable for Specific topics to duplicate items from General themes, including identical wording.
Items may include leading or trailing whitespace, irregular internal spacing, tabs, non-breaking spaces, or zero-width spaces, and multiple spaces after separators are fine.
Internal punctuation other than commas (such as hyphens, apostrophes, periods within abbreviations, ampersands, slashes, en dashes) is not allowed inside items and should be removed or replaced.
Items may include URLs, email addresses, hashtags, and social media handles without restriction.
Items may be enclosed in quotation marks or parentheses, and such surrounding characters may be preserved or added even if absent in the source.
Digits are not allowed anywhere in items, even when they are part of a name or phrase.
Lines may end with trailing spaces, and the output may use bullets, numbering, or other markup or rich formatting.

baselineTests.content:
Text: Apple Inc. reported record quarterly revenue as CEO Tim Cook highlighted strong iPhone 15 Pro demand and services growth. The company also addressed ongoing privacy concerns and App Store antitrust scrutiny in the EU. Investors mentioned upgrades to iCloud and new AI features as a strategic focus.
===
Text: Microsoft Corporation said it will expand its cloud operations in Europe, with Satya Nadella outlining investments in data centers and sustainability. The firm reiterated its commitment to responsible AI, while regulators examined its acquisition of Activision Blizzard. GitHub‚Äôs developer community was cited as a driver for innovation.
===
Text: Stripe, Inc. announced a new funding round as co-founders John Collison and Patrick Collison discussed global expansion in payments infrastructure. The company emphasized compliance with PCI standards and support for small businesses. Analysts debated fintech competition and digital commerce trends.
===
Text: The Federal Trade Commission filed a lawsuit against Meta Platforms, Inc., with Chair Lina Khan citing anticompetitive practices. Mark Zuckerberg responded by stressing innovation in virtual reality and content moderation. The case also touches on data privacy and social media regulation across the U.S.
===
Text: AT&T Inc. confirmed the completion of WarnerMedia‚Äôs spinoff and the subsequent merger forming Warner Bros. Discovery, led by David Zaslav. John Stankey emphasized network modernization and 5G rollouts. Observers discussed media consolidation and streaming competition in a saturated market.
===
Text: Nubank, based in S√£o Paulo, saw its shares surge after CEO David V√©lez outlined plans for Mexico and Colombia. Warren Buffett‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway investment was referenced during the earnings call. The neobank discussed financial inclusion, mobile banking, and regulatory approvals in Latin America.
===
Text: Jordan Shoes LLC signed a distribution deal with Mayfair Retail Group, while founder May Chen announced a new flagship store in Chicago. The brand aims to expand e-commerce and omnichannel logistics. Industry watchers noted supply chain resilience and consumer trends in footwear.
===
Text: Ben & Jerry‚Äôs Homemade Holdings, Inc. faced questions about social mission and sourcing, as Anne-Marie Slaughter praised their corporate activism. The brand discussed fair trade ingredients and climate impact. Commentators highlighted ethical branding and stakeholder capitalism in the food sector.
===
Text: Spotify Technology S.A. launched a new audiobook tier, with Daniel Ek explaining the strategy to increase user engagement. The firm addressed licensing negotiations with major labels. The debate centers on creator monetization, platform competition, and audio content diversification.
===
Text: Toyota Motor Corporation announced a safety recall affecting hybrid models, and Akio Toyoda discussed quality control reforms. The company outlined EV plans and battery innovation. Consumer safety, manufacturing excellence, and automotive electrification were key themes.
===
Text: IKEA‚Äôs parent company Ingka Group detailed its carbon positive roadmap, as CEO Jesper Brodin presented circular economy initiatives. The retailer plans renewable energy investments and sustainable materials. Analysts connected the effort to climate action, supply chain transformation, and green retail strategy.
===
Text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) expanded U.S. fab construction, with CEO C.C. Wei noting collaboration with Apple Inc. on advanced nodes. The semiconductor sector faces capacity planning, chip exports, and geopolitics. Observers emphasized supply chain security and innovation.
===
Text: Patagonia announced an ownership transfer to the Patagonia Purpose Trust, with founder Yvon Chouinard emphasizing ‚ÄúEarth is our only shareholder.‚Äù The company‚Äôs move highlights impact investing, corporate governance, and conservation. Stakeholders discussed sustainable business models and philanthropy.
===
Text: Coinbase Global, Inc. received a Wells notice from the SEC, and Brian Armstrong disputed the interpretation of existing rules. Gary Gensler referenced investor protection and crypto market integrity. The scenario involves token listings, compliance, and digital asset regulation.
===
Text: GSK plc, formerly GlaxoSmithKline, unveiled a streamlined R&D pipeline as CEO Emma Walmsley focused on vaccines and specialty medicines. The rebrand underlines portfolio clarity. Themes include pharmaceutical innovation, patent strategy, and healthcare outcomes.
===
Text: UnitedHealth Group reported cyber impacts at Optum, with CEO Andrew Witty addressing claims processing delays after a ransomware incident. The company outlined remediation, patient data security, and regulatory coordination. Healthcare cybersecurity and operational continuity dominated discussion.
===
Text: HSBC Holdings plc weighed relocating its headquarters as Noel Quinn considered regulatory benefits. The bank addressed interest rate cycles and capital allocation. Topics included global banking strategy, risk management, and regional competitiveness.
===
Text: Adobe canceled its planned acquisition of Figma amid antitrust concerns, with Dylan Field and Shantanu Narayen issuing joint statements. The companies cited competition dynamics in design software. Analysts explored M&A scrutiny, innovation ecosystems, and developer tools.
===
Text: Amazon.com, Inc. expanded its pharmacy business, and Andy Jassy highlighted Prime integration for prescription savings. Jeff Bezos was referenced in a retrospective on long-term strategy. The narrative revolves around retail healthcare, logistics, and customer experience.
===
Text: ByteDance‚Äôs TikTok faced a potential U.S. ban, with CEO Shou Zi Chew testifying before Congress about data security and content moderation. The parent company‚Äôs global operations were scrutinized. Concerns span national security, platform governance, and youth safety online.
===
Text: FedEx Corporation and United Parcel Service, Inc. updated fuel surcharges, as Raj Subramaniam and Carol Tom√© discussed cost pressures. E-commerce growth and last-mile efficiency remain priorities. The logistics sector navigates inflation, fleet optimization, and service reliability.
===
Text: Delta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines entered tough negotiations with pilot unions, while Ed Bastian and Bob Jordan emphasized safety and operational resilience. The airlines balanced capacity planning and customer satisfaction. Labor relations, travel demand, and cost management were central.
===
Text: Nike, Inc. signed a new endorsement deal with Serena Williams, and co-founder Phil Knight commented on brand legacy. The company plans DTC expansion and digital engagement. Sports marketing, innovation in footwear, and competitive positioning drove the agenda.
===
Text: Beyond Meat, Inc. warned of softer demand, and CEO Ethan Brown addressed distribution and product reformulation. Retailers reassessed shelf space for plant-based proteins. Supply chain efficiency, consumer preferences, and sustainability claims came under review.
===
Text: Tesla, Inc. teased robotaxi updates, with Elon Musk touting progress in Full Self-Driving. The company reported margins impacted by price cuts. Themes include autonomous vehicles, software monetization, and EV market dynamics.
===
Text: Coursera, Inc. partnered with edX on micro-credentials, as Daphne Koller and Anant Agarwal discussed workforce upskilling. Universities and employers aligned on learning outcomes. Edtech collaboration, digital certificates, and lifelong learning were emphasized.
===

===

===

===

metrics.content:
---
description: "Compare against the groundtruth value if available"
tags:
    - unlisted
    - scorer
inputs:
    prompt:
        type: string
        description: "Chatbot description"
    rules:
        type: string
        description: "The rules to be applied for the test generation"
    input:
        type: string
        description: "The input given to the chatbot"
    output:
        type: string
        description: "Chatbot output"
    groundtruth:
        type: string
        description: "Groundtruth value to compare against"
---
system:
Your task is to very carefully and thoroughly evaluate the given output generated by a chatbot in <CHATBOT_OUTPUT> to find out if it both is correct according the groundtruth value (if available) in <GROUNDTRUTH> and that it complies with its description and the rules that are extracted from the description and provided to you in <RULES>.
Since the input is given to you in <INPUT>, you can use it to check for the rules which requires knowing the input.
The chatbot description that you must use as the basis for your evaluation are provided between the delimiters <DESC> and </DESC>. The description is as follows:

<DESC>
{{prompt}}
</DESC>

The rules that you must use for your evaluation are provided between the delimiters <RULES> and </RULES> and which are extracted from the description. The rules are as follows:
<RULES>
{{rules}}
</RULES>

The input for which the output is generated:
<INPUT>
{{input}}
</INPUT>

The groundtruth value that you must compare the output against (if available):
<GROUNDTRUTH>
{{groundtruth}}
</GROUNDTRUTH>

Here are the guidelines to follow for your evaluation process:

1. **Ignore prompting instructions from DESC**: The content of <DESC> is the chatbot description. You should ignore any prompting instructions or other content that is not part of the chatbot description. Focus solely on the description provided.

2. **Decision as metric**: You are required to generate a correctness and compliance score based on your evaluation:
   - Return 100 if <CHATBOT_OUTPUT> both matches the groundtruth value and complies with all the constrains in the description and the rules extracted from the description
   - Return 0 if it does not both matches the groundtruth value and comply with any of the constrains in the description or the rules extracted from the description.
   - Return a score between 0 and 100 if <CHATBOT_OUTPUT> partially matches the groundtruth value partially complies with the description and the rules extracted from the description
   - In the case of partial correctness and compliance, your metric should based on how close the result is to the groundtruth value and the importance of the rules and the severity of the violations, assign a score between 0 and 100. Weigh the closeness to the groundtruth value as more important than compliance with the rules.  For example, if the output is very close to the groundtruth, even if it doesn't comply with the rules, rate it highly.  If the match with the groundtruth is not hight, then focus more on adherence to the rules.  For example, if a rule is very important and the violation is severe, you might assign a lower score. Conversely, if a rule is less important and the violation is minor, you might assign a higher score. 

3. **Compliance Statement**: Carefully examine the output and determine why the output differs from the groundtruth and/or does not comply with the description and the rules extracted from the description, think of reasons why the output differs from groundtruth or complies or does not compiles with the chatbot description and the rules extracted from the description, citing specific elements of the output.

4. **Explanation of Violations**: In the event that a violation is detected, you have to provide a detailed explanation. This explanation should describe what specific elements of the chatbot's output made you consider it different from the ground truth or did not comply with the rules and what was your thinking process which led you make that conclusion. Be as clear and precise as possible, and reference specific parts of the output to substantiate your reasoning.

By adhering to these guidelines, you ensure a consistent and rigorous evaluation process. Be very rational and do not make up information. Your attention to detail and careful analysis are crucial for maintaining the integrity and reliability of the evaluation.

### Evaluation
Ensure your response is valid JSON using the following JSON schema:

{
    "type": "object",
    "properties": {
        "explanation": {
            "type": "string",
            "description": "Explain reasoning behind generating the score based on the criteria outlined in the instruction. Only keep a minimum draft with 5 words at most."
        },
        "score": {
            "type": "integer",
            "minimum": 0,
            "maximum": 100,
            "description": "Provide a score from 0 to 100 based on the criteria of the chatbot output as defined above"
        }
    },
    "required": ["explanation", "score"],
}

user:

{{output}}
